Graphical abstract Despite tremendous efforts, developing a series of heterogeneous catalysts for CO oxidation elimination with high activity at low cost remains a great challenge. Here, we report a bifunctional Co-based nanocrystals anchoring in the graphene oxide layer as a high-performance catalyst for CO oxidation. Although a single cobalt or graphene oxide catalysts alone have the lower catalytic activity, their combination exhibits an unexpected, surprisingly high CO activity that is further enhanced by a series of oxygen-containing functional groups on the surface of graphene oxide sheets. The Co/graphene oxide calcined at 300°C (Co/GO–300°C) exhibits the outstanding catalytic activity with T100 =51°C but superior stability, producing a high-performance non-precious metal-based catalyst for CO oxidation elimination. Under a series of critical characterizations, the unusual catalytic activity of Co/GO–300°C sample is attributed to the synergistic effect between the oxygen-containing functional groups of graphene oxide sheets and Co species. Especially, the existence of Co3+ species could promote the adsorption and activation of CO molecules. Keywords CO oxidation Synergistic effect Graphene Cobalt Bifunctional catalyst Introduction It is highly challenging but desirable to design efficient catalysts for the elimination of various contaminants through oxidation means, particularly for toxic gases CO. Catalysts for CO oxidation reactions are at the heart of the elimination and control of air pollutants in cities deriving from gasoline and diesel internal combustion engine vehicles [1–3]. Therefore, it is necessary to mitigate the harmful impact of CO on the environment and constrain the emission of CO through the catalytic process. Until now, various types of heterogeneous catalysts have been synthesized and employed to eliminate the pollution of CO [4–7]. Although tremendous efforts were devoted, it remains a great challenge to develop the low temperature catalysts with high activity at low cost. Notably, the current bottleneck of CO oxidation catalyst lies in the development of highly efficient and inexpensive catalysts at low temperature. Among heterogeneous catalysts, precious metal-based catalyst has advanced undoubtedly, as Haruta et al. reported that the very high catalytic activity of Au particles below 5nm are dispersed on base metal oxides for low temperature CO oxidation [8]. Due to its high cost and harsh conditions, alternative catalysts based on non-precious metals [9–12] and metal-free materials [13–16] have been actively pursued. It is highly desirable to develop a highly efficient non-precious metal-based catalysts for CO oxidation at low temperature, which could eliminate and control CO pollutants deriving from gasoline and diesel internal combustion engine vehicles, and avoid the using of precious metal-based catalysts. Accordingly, various non-precious materials are investigated including CuO, CeO2, Co3O4 and son on, which own relatively the excellent catalytic performance in low temperature CO oxidation [5,17–19]. According to the literatures [20,21], it is reported that Co3O4 is active intrinsically for CO oxidation, even at room temperature. However, most of the active sites of Co3O4 are covered by H2O in the reaction, which hindered appreciably the adsorption of CO and oxygen, and inhibited unquestionably the conversion of CO [22]. In order to avoid this phenomenon, a series of supported Co-based catalysts were investigated. Alumina-supported Co3O4 was reported to give 50% CO conversion at 263°C for a normal feed gas, but a low CO conversion was obtained at high temperature [23]. Contrary to Co3O4/Al2O3, Co3O4/SiO2 catalyst gave poor performances in CO oxidation, and the reason is that the silica is not able to thermally stabilize cobalt oxide [24]. Additionally, Kang et al. [25] also reported that CoOx/Al2O3 and CoOx/zeolite Y were significantly less active in wet conditions (T50 =222 and 537.8°C, respectively). Likewise, Co nanoparticles were also dispersed on MgO, with maximum CO activity at 37wt% cobalt loading [26]. The above supported Co-based catalysts are extremely sensitive to the pretreatment temperature. Unexpectedly, the activity increased between 300 and 400°C, and then slowly decreased with the further increase of pretreatment temperature, as 700°C with the lower activity. In total, although most of the supported Co-based catalysts own the excellent stability at a normal feed gas, the high temperature is needed, even above a temperature of 200°C. Therefore, intensive research efforts are contributed to discover an efficient supported Co-based catalyst with higher activity and stability for CO oxidation at low temperature. To the best our knowledge, there is scarcely report about CO complete conversion at 50°C via the supported Co-based catalysts. It has been focused that the participation of support is significantly critical for fully stimulating the role of active metal components [27]. Graphene, a special carbon-based material widely applied in catalysis, energy, environment and other fields, has served as a reliable support for various heterogeneous catalysts with the high surface area and the rich oxygen-containing functional groups [28–30]. Wu et al. reported that the graphene is considered as a good support to disperse Fe atom as catalysts for CO oxidation [31]. Krishnan et al. also discovered through DFT calculations that penta-graphene could be treated as a metal-free catalyst for CO oxidation [32]. In this work, we introduced graphene materials into the cobalt-based system through a typical hydrothermal method. It is discovered that nanoscale cobalt particles were anchored in the graphene oxide (GO) layer, exhibiting surprisingly high activity and superior stability, thus leading to a new bifunctional catalyst for CO oxidation. This bifunctional Co/GO catalyst was synthesized in solution, and exhibited the outstanding CO activity at low temperature, and with the relatively prominent long-term stability. Materials and methods Materials Natural graphite powder (purity 99.9995%), sulphuric acid (95–97%), hydrazine hydrate (80%), ethylene glycol and anhydrous sodium carbonate (50%) were purchased from Shanghai Aladdin Reagent Co Ltd. Potassium peroxydisulfate (K2S2O8), phosphorus pentoxide (P2O5) and potassium permanganate (KMnO4), cobalt acetate tetrahydrate (Co(C2H3O2)2·4H2O) was purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd In general, all of the chemicals were used as received without further purification. Preparation of graphene oxide (GO), Co/GO, Co/RGO and Co/RG Graphene oxide (GO) was synthesized by oxidative stripping of natural graphite powder under acidic conditions according to the Hummers method using a mixture of H2SO4, K2S2O8, P2O5 and KMnO4 [33]. In a typical synthesis of the Co/graphene oxide materials, 2.49g of cobalt acetate tetrahydrate [Co(C2H3O2)2·4H2O] was dispersed in 36mL of distilled water. At the same time, in order to obtain uniform dispersion of graphene oxide hybrids (GO), 0.5g of graphite oxide was dispersed in 500mL (1mg/mL) water by sonication for 2h. After that, cobalt acetate solution was slowly dropped into the uniform GO solution. Subsequently, 1M anhydrous sodium carbonate solution were added to the above solution, and a mixed solution of graphene oxide and cobalt ions is precipitated gradually at water bath system. Then, the mixture was transferred into an autoclave for hydrothermal treatment at 150°C under static condition for 10h. After hydrothermal treatment, all precursors were filtrated, washed with ethanol and hot deionized water, and dried overnight at 60°C to obtain precursor powder. After drying, these samples were calcined in pure N2 atmosphere (≥99.999%) for 5h, and the final product was labeled as Co/GO (Co/graphene oxide). After calcination, the mass percentage of metal Co was 45.7% in all catalysts. For a comparison, pure cobalt sample and bare graphene oxide were also synthesized with the same method. In the process, the amount of anhydrous sodium carbonate can ensure that the metal Co ions were completely precipitated. Typically, the synthesis process of the Co/GO hybrids is schematically illustrated in Fig. 1 . Similarly, Co/RGO (Co/reduced graphene oxide) sample is prepared using the same method, and the difference is that cobalt acetate tetrahydrate [Co(C2H3O2)2·4H2O] was dispersed in 36mL of ethylene glycol. In addition, Co/RG (Co/graphene) sample is also prepared with 36mL of ethylene glycol, and then added 10mL hydrazine hydrate to remove oxygen-containing functional groups of graphene oxide sheets. Catalyst characterization Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis was performed on a Rigaku D/MAX-RB X-ray diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ=1.5418Å), and the scanning angle ranged from 10° to 80° of 2θ. Raman scattering was performed on a RM 2000 microscope confocal Raman spectrometer (Renishaw PLC) with 514nm laser. Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) spectra were recorded on a Nexus 870 infrared spectrometer with a resolution of 4cm−1 in transmission mode at room temperature. The chemical states of elements of samples surface were investigated by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) on a VG ESCALAB 210 Electron Spectrometer with Mg Kα radiation, and the spectra were corrected by using the C1s binding energy of 284.6eV as the standard. The morphology of the samples were investigated by using Field emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM, JSM-6701F) at 30kV, and the nanostructures of the samples were characterized on a JEOL JEM-2010 transmission electron microscope operating at 200kV, and a suspension of the sample in ethanol was drop-casted onto carbon-coated copper grids and dried under ambient conditions. Catalyst performance To evaluate the activity in CO oxidation reaction, the experiments were carried out in a continuous-flow fixed-bed glass tube reactor (6.0mm inner diameter). In a typical run, 1 Vol.% CO/air with 1000ppm CO was transferred into the reactor at a total flow rate of 50mLmin−1 and a definite amount of catalyst (300mg) was added to the isothermal region of the reactor tube. A typical weigh hourly space velocity (WHSV) was 10,000mLg−1 h−1. Typically, under normal conditions, 1 Vol.% CO/air was introduced the reactor. Under humid conditions, water vapor was mixed with 1 Vol.% CO/air through bubble method, and then introduced into the reactor. A series of catalysts were tested to investigate the effect of oxygen-containing functional groups in graphene oxide and Co species for CO oxidation elimination. After each round of reaction, the gas was also determined using an on-line gas chromatograph (GC-7890, Agilent, USA) equipped with a thermal conductivity detector and a molecular sieve 5A column. In this paper, this change of moles was neglected. Therefore, CO conversion rate (XCO) was calculated: X CO = ( [ CO ] in Vol. % − [ CO ] out Vol. % ) ( [ CO ] in Vol. % × 100 Results and Discussion The effect of oxygen-containing functional groups from Co/GO, Co/RGO and Co/RG materials Raman spectroscopy is a powerful tool to rapidly and nondestructively verify the intrinsic physical properties of carbon nanostructures, including graphene, carbon nanotubes and so on. The Raman spectra of natural graphite powder showed in Fig. 2 a, and the oxidative stripping graphene oxide was exhibited in Fig. 2b. According to the Raman spectra of graphene oxide (GO), the G band (∼1595cm−1) corresponding to sp2-hybridized carbon, and the D band (∼1352cm−1) originating from disordered carbon is observed for graphene oxide [34,35]. The 2D represents the vibrational mode of the two photon lattices, which is the doubling peak of the D peak. Unlike D peak, 2D peaks do not need to be activated near the atoms into defects. Generally, the ratio between the intensity of 2D and G bands has been widely used to evaluate the layer number of graphene coarsely. For monolayer graphene samples, the 2D peak is a single symmetric peak with a half width of about 30cm−1. As the number of layers increases, the symmetry decreases and the 2D peaks split into multiple overlapping peaks. For samples with a layer number less than 4, this apparent peak change can effectively distinguish the number of graphene layers. The monolayer graphene can also be identified by the intensity of the I2D/IG ratio. The I2D/IG of the high-quality (non-defective) monolayer graphene is 2, and as the ratio decreases, the number of graphene layers is getting thicker. In Fig. 2, the symmetry of the 2D peaks indicates non-monolayer graphene, and the thickness of the graphene oxide is estimated about 4 layers. The above results indicated that natural graphite powder has been successfully stripped into graphene oxide sheets with various oxygen-containing functional groups, which is favorable to the adsorption and activation of oxygen molecules. On the other hand, these rich oxygen-containing functional groups of graphene oxide sheets could also promote the dispersion and anchoring of metal nanoparticles. The Co/graphene materials were investigated by X-ray diffraction to distinguish the phase, as shown in Fig. 3 a. For the X-ray diffraction peak of Co/graphene (Co/RG) sample, the peaks at 2θ values of 19.3° (111), 31.5° (220), 36.8° (311), 45.0° (400), 59.6° (511) and 65.4° (440) are consistent with the standard XRD data for the cubic phase Co3O4 (JCPDS card No. 42–1467). Interestingly, the diffraction peaks of Co/reduced graphene oxide (Co/RGO) and Co/graphene oxide (Co/GO) are almost identical, indicating that the phase was evidently shifted due to the addition of hydrazine hydrate. For Co/RGO and Co/GO samples, the peaks at 2θ values of 36.5°(311), 42.4° (400) and 61.5° (220) are consistent with the standard XRD data for the cubic phase CoO (JCPDS card No. 48–1719). Notably, the diffraction peak for C(002) in graphene is invisible in three samples, suggesting that significant face-to-face stacking is destruct due to the introduction of Co nanoparticles on both sides of graphene sheets [36]. In order to further investigate the structure difference of Co/GO and Co/RGO, we conducted the analysis of Raman spectra in Fig. 3b. In the Raman spectra of these two samples, it has been reported that the G band (∼1595cm−1) corresponding to sp2-hybridized carbon, and the D band (∼1352cm−1) originating from disordered carbon is observed for graphene oxide [34,35]. Similarly, the peaks of Raman shift at 480cm−1, 525cm−1 and 682cm−1 are ascribed to the Eg, F2g and A1g modes of Co3O4, respectively [37,38]. We note that the Raman peaks of CoO bands in Co/GO–450°C sample are conspicuously enhanced, while in Co/RGO–450°C sample, the Raman peaks of CoO bands are very weak due to the addition of ethylene glycol, which could capture oxygen atoms from cobalt oxides. Likewise, in FT-IR spectra of Co/GO, Co/RGO and Co/RG materials (Fig. 4 ), the absorption band at 597 and 660cm−1 can be assigned to the vibrations of CoO bands [39]. The absorption at 1721cm−1 can be assigned to the stretching vibration of CO groups arising from COO [40]. After the addition of ethylene glycol and hydrazine hydrate, it is discovered that the oxygen-containing functional groups of graphene oxide were distinctly weakened, and especially the addition of hydrazine hydrate unexpectedly decreased the number of oxygen-containing functional groups. On the other hand, the addition of hydrazine hydrate also disrupted the CoO bands, resulting in the weakness of CoO bands in FT-IR spectra, as Co/RG–450°C sample. Most importantly, the oxidation performance of Co/GO, Co/RGO and Co/RG materials was compared at the same conditions (Fig. 5 ). It is discovered that the Co/GO–450°C sample exhibited the best CO conversion, and could convert completely CO into CO2 at 57°C, while other two samples both need to the higher temperature above 60°C. The reason may be related to the effect of oxygen-containing functional groups, which play a key role in the activation of oxygen (O2) molecules. Combined with FT-IR results, Co/GO–450°C sample own the strongest characteristic peaks of CO and −OH groups, indicating that the well-dispersed nanoscale Co particles on graphene oxide sheets not only effectively inhibited the agglomeration of graphene oxide layer, which resulted in the production of double active sites, but also promoted the dispersion and anchoring of Co nanoparticles. Additionally, considering that the electronic valence of metal cobalt is also vital for improving the activity of Co/GO materials, and it is necessary to further explore the role of Co3+/Co2+ species in CO oxidation reaction. Herein, we increased the pre-calcination temperature of Co/GO materials to tune the ratio of the valence of metal cobalt. To remain essentially unchanged the number of oxygen-containing functional groups on graphene oxide sheets, pure N2 atmosphere (≥99.999%) was accordingly used in the roasting process. CO oxidation performance and structure of Co/graphene oxide materials at the different calcination temperature CO oxidation performance of Co/GO materials calcined at different temperatures are presented in Fig. 6 a, and CO activity is compared at the same conditions. The well-dispersed Co nanoparticles on graphene oxide sheets not only effectively inhibited the agglomeration, which resulted in a high activity at low temperature, but also changed the number of Co3+/Co2+ species due to the modulation of calcination temperature. The activity was improved with the increase of calcination temperature due to the deposition of cobalt species. In particular, the sample that was annealed at 300°C had the highest CO activity, while the continue enhancement of calcination temperature would lead to an obvious decline of CO conversion. The reason may be ascribed to the difference of Co3+ and Oa species on the surface of these catalysts, because the modulation of calcination temperature not only promotes the formation of Co3+ species, and also leads to the transformation of Oa species. The detailed analysis see in section 3.3. Notably, Co/GO–300°C sample possess the best catalytic activity due to the formation of Co3O4 phase, and thus we investigated the stability of Co/GO–300°C sample under normal and humid conditions, respectively (Fig. 6b). It is discovered that the Co/GO–300°C sample is stable inherently during CO oxidation reaction under normal conditions. When water vapor was introduced into reactor at the same conditions, CO conversion exhibited a slight decline. From XRD patterns of Co/GO materials at the different calcination temperature (Fig. 7 ), the positions and relative intensities of diffraction peaks match well with the standard of Co3O4, Co2O3, CoO species and graphene patterns [36,41,42]. The peaks at 2θ values of 31.5° (220), 37.0° (311), and 45.0° (400) are consistent with the standard XRD data of the phase Co3O4 (JCPDS no. 42-1467), and the peak of 42.1° (200) was assigned to the existence of CoO (JCPDS no. 43-1004). The additive peaks at 53.1° can be attributed to the presence of Co2O3 phase (JCPDS no. 42-0770). Notably, Co/GO–150°C sample appeared no obvious diffraction peak of cobalt oxide and graphene, indicating that Co species is highly dispersed on graphene oxide layer. Simultaneously, no apparent additional peaks is observed on the Co/GO–300°C sample, suggesting that is of high purity Co3O4 phase. Furthermore, for Co/GO–450°C catalyst, it is observed that the diffraction peaks of Co3O4 and CoO phase were exhibited uncommonly, which could be ascribed to the effect of calcination temperature. However, the diffraction peaks of Co/GO–600°C were significantly inconsistent with the other three samples, and appeared as the presence of Co3O4 and Co2O3 phase. In summary, the difference of cobalt oxides in the Co/GO system is mainly due to the modulation of calcination temperature, which could tune the chemical state of metal cobalt and strengthen the interaction of Co nanoparticles and graphene oxide sheets. Besides, the Co crystallite size of Co/GO samples was calculated according to the Scherrer equation, the values were respectively 18.0, 17.5 and 21.9nm in Table 1. Evidently, Co/GO–150°C sample showed the smallest crystalline size, and the crystalline size below 4nm cannot be detected by XRD technique [43]. The phases of Co/graphene oxide materials at the different calcination temperature are further confirmed by Raman spectroscopy. The Raman spectra of Co/graphene oxide materials are shown in Fig. 8 . The peaks detected at around 480cm−1, 525cm−1 and 682cm−1 are assigned to the Eg, F2g and A1g modes of Co3O4, respectively [37,38]. In addition, the broad peaks at 1360cm−1 and 1595cm−1 are observed, which are related to the D and G bands of graphene sheets. The D band is attributed to the mode of the k-point phonons of A1g symmetry, connecting with the defects of graphene oxide materials, and the G band corresponds to the E2g phonon of Csp2 atoms [34,35]. Generally, the ratio between the intensity of D and G bands has been widely used to evaluate the quality of graphene materials [44]. However, the ID/IG ratio of Co/GO materials is smaller than that of GO, suggesting that the backbone of graphene oxide sheets has been recovered by Co nanoparticles to some extent (Table 1 ). These results further verify the coexistence of both graphene oxide sheets and Co nanoparticles in the as-prepared samples. To investigate the chemical states of elements in Co/GO materials, the XPS analysis was carried out on these samples in Fig. 8. The XPS analysis was used to identify surface chemical states and the compositions of Co/GO materials, and the results were exhibited in Fig. 9 a. The Co2p XPS spectra of the Co/GO materials exhibit two peaks at 796.5 and 780.9eV, corresponding to the Co 2p1/2 and Co 2p3/2 spin-orbit peaks of Co3O4 [45]. The presence of Co3O4 phase can be further confirmed by the O 1s XPS peak at 530.1eV, which corresponds to the oxygen species in the Co3O4 phase. The C1s (284.6eV) peak observed is related to graphitic carbon in graphene oxide sheets, and the small O1s peak at 532.0eV in the spectrum indicates the presence of residual oxygen-containing groups (such as −OH and −COOH) bonded with C atoms in graphene oxide sheets. The Co2p X-ray photoelectron spectra derived from the Co/GO materials fired at the different temperature were all similar in Fig. 9b and resemble that recorded from Co3O4 [46]. Thus, the XPS spectrum of Co/GO materials were analyzed on the basis of the fitting of the spectrum of Co3O4. According to the literature [47], the Co2p is characterized by two components Co2p3/2 and Co2p1/2, which appear due to the spin orbital splitting and shake up satellites. The satellite at 788.1eV (Sat. 1) is likely to be associated with the Co3+ component of Co3O4, and the satellite peak at 803.4eV (Sat. 2) is related to the Co 2p spectra of CoO and Co3O4 [48]. These components are enormously significant for the analysis of cobalt state, which is related to the binding energy separation of the satellite signals and spin orbital splitting. The literatures [49–51] has reported the assignment of the different peaks in the XPS spectra. In these four samples, all the spectra show typical components due to the coexistence of Co2+ and Co3+ species, with the Co3+/(Co3+ +Co2+ +Sat) ratio being exhibited in Table 2. It is discovered that the relative ratio of Co3+ species increased firstly with the increase of calcination temperature, and then decreased with the continuous increase. As the calcination temperature is 300°C, the content of Co3+ species in Co/graphene oxide system is the highest. In addition, the predominant O1s peak at 531.54 and 532.41eV belongs to the lattice oxygen combined with Co2+ and Co3+ species in Co3O4 [52]. From Fig. 10 , the O1s spectra of samples can be fitted to three types of peaks, including the lattice oxygen (Ol), the chemisorbed oxygen (Oa) and the adsorbed water species (Ow) [53–55]. The Ol species at 529.6eV is typical of metal-oxygen bonds due to the lattice oxygen of metal oxides with lower binding energy, the Oa species at 530.7eV is as a result of the chemisorbed oxygen, and the Ow peak at 532.1eV is ascribed to multiplicity of physi- and chemisorbed water at and within the surface. It has been reported that the surface chemisorbed O atoms (Oa) is specially active for the oxidation of CO [56], because their mobility is higher than that of the lattice O atoms (Ol), with the Oa/(Ol +Oa +Ow) ratio being exhibited in Table 2 . Notably, it is discovered that the relative Oa/(Ol +Oa +Ow) value increased with the increasing of calcination temperature. When the calcination temperature is 450°C, Co/graphene oxide system exhibits the highest value of Oa specie.. The morphology and microstructure of graphene oxide and Co/GO–300°C materials are shown in Fig. 11 . Clearly, Fig. 11a depicts transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images of the graphene oxide sheets we obtained. The thickness is roughly estimated from the diffractive ring of carbon (Fig. 11b), indicating that the formation of a thinner layer for the graphene oxide. Transmission electron microscopy of Co/GO–300°C sample (Fig. 11c) reveals that the sample is mainly composed of Co nanoparticles that associated with the hydrothermal graphene oxide layer. Similarly, the field-emission scanning electron microscopic (FE-SEM) image of Co/GO–300°C sample (Fig. 11d) confirms that Co nanoparticles (many small dark dots) were uniformly dispersed and anchored in the thin layer of graphene oxide. The good dispersion of Co nanoparticles around graphene oxide sheets is most likely owing to the existence of various oxygen-containing functional groups on the graphene oxide sheets, which provided sufficient anchoring sites for loading the precursors of metallic Co nanoparticles. Synergistic mechanism of Co&+ species and the containing-oxygen functional groups in CO oxidation reaction It has been reported that CO molecule has three resonance structures, which can explain its adsorption properties and reactivity on metal surfaces [10]. Generally, CO molecule can be connected to one (linear species) or several metal atoms (bridged species). CO molecule is treated as an electron donor, which can coordinate to the surface of metal sites via the 5s orbital mainly localized on C. On the contrary, CO molecule also acts as a π acceptor through the antibonding 2π* orbital [57]. It is also reported that O2 molecule could dissociatively adsorb on two adjacent metal atoms surface at ambient temperature [10]. To verify the reaction mechanism, Broqvist et al. [58] and Xu et al. [59] developed a model of the cobalt oxide surface using DFT calculations: The model is based on the Co3O4 (110) orientation of the spinel crystal that may be cut along the A plane or the B plane (Fig. S2). On the A plane, two Co2+ cations (Cotet in the tetrahedral sites), two Co3+ (Cooct in the octahedral sites) and four O2− anions are exposed. On the B plane, there are two Co3+ (Cooct) and four O2− anions. In this work, it is discovered that the oxygen-containing functional groups of graphene oxide sheets and the valence of metal cobalt play the key role in CO oxidation reaction. Herein, we semi-quantitatively calculated the number of Co3+ species and Oa species in Co/GO system on basis of the area of their XPS peaks, and the results are shown in Table 2. From Table 2, with the increase of calcination temperature, the relative ratio of Co3+/(Co3+ +Co2+ +Sat) is as follows: Co/GO–300°C>Co/GO–150°C>Co/GO–450°C>Co/GO–600°C. In addition, the Oa/(Ol +Oa +Ow) ratio increased to 5.5% for Co/GO–450°C sample, meaning the catalysts with the relative high calcination temperature possessed the more chemisorbed oxygen species than those at lower calcination temperature. However, the further increase of calcination temperature would lead to the obvious decrease of chemisorbed oxygen species (Oa), as Co/GO–600°C sample. The above results verified that Co/GO–300°C catalyst possesses the highest Co3+ species, and Co/GO–450°C catalyst possesses the highest chemisorbed oxygen species (Oa). Co/GO–300°C catalyst could afford stronger coupling between Co3+ species and the oxygen-containing functional groups of graphene oxide sheets than other three samples. After calcination at 300°C, graphene oxide serves as favorable nucleation and anchoring sites for Co nanoparticles owing to coordination with Co cations. This is well-consistent with a smaller Co3O4 nanocrystal size (higher nucleation degree) on Co/GO than on Co/RGO and Co/RG catalysts. Electronic effects of the oxygen-containing functional groups of graphene oxide sheets could also play an important role in the activation of O2 molecular. Note that the oxygen-containing functional groups contains a large amount of electrons, which is believed to be a key active site to promote the conversion of CO. It is supported that the Co/GO catalyst dealt with 300°C emerged the lowest CO oxidation temperature due to the formation of Co3+ species, which could adsorb a large number of CO molecule. Simultaneously, Co/GO–300°C catalyst also exhibit higher stability, differ in solution-phase synthesis process, and the Co species in Co/GO–300°C catalyst is in the form of Co3O4 phase (see XRD and XPS in Fig. 7 and Fig. 9). More importantly, in order to further verify the contribution of double active sites (oxygen-containing functional groups and Co species), we also used the same method to prepare a single cobalt and graphene oxide as references, and compared the performance in CO oxidation at the same conditions (Fig. 12 and Table S1). Combined with a series of characterizations, it is indicated that the valence of metal cobalt, the smaller Co nanoparticles and suitable containing-oxygen functional groups of graphene oxide sheets are responsible for high activity of Co/GO–300°C catalyst, notably indicating that synergistic coupling between the highly dispersed Co nanoparticles and graphene oxide is indispensable to the high CO activity. In further, confirming that the active sites in CO oxidation for our Co/GO materials could be assigned to the common contribution of Co3+ species and electron-rich oxygen-containing functional groups at the interface of Co nanocrystals and graphene oxide sheets. It has been reported that the oxygen-containing functional groups on the surface of graphene oxide can transfer electrons to the O2 molecules through the phase interface and promote the decomposition of O2 into active oxygen O* species, thus accelerating the oxidation rate of CO [60,61]. Besides, the surface of graphene oxide owns the rich oxygen-containing functional groups, such as hydroxyl, epoxy, in the edge contains carbonyl and carboxyl, etc., which provide the loading conditions for the active metal components. The highly dispersed Co nanoparticles are favorable for the adsorption and activation of CO molecules, especially the existence of Co3+ species, which can promote the activation of CO molecules in Scheme 1 . Likewise, the electrons on the Pz orbital of C atom from graphene oxide sheet hybridized with the d orbital electrons of cobalt component, thus affecting the activity of cobalt oxide. For Co/GO–300°C sample, we anchored Co nanoparticles in the graphene oxide layer and evaluated its performance in CO oxidation reaction at low temperature, affording a complete conversion of CO at 51°C. Compared to the performance of a single cobalt catalyst, it is discovered that the mechanically mixed graphene and cobalt catalysts exhibited the higher CO conversion at the same conditions (Fig. 12). These results confirmed that Co nanoparticles anchoring in the graphene oxide layer has considered as the efficient bifunctional catalyst to promote the activation of oxygen molecular and the adsorption of CO molecules, presenting the highest performance than pure Co-based catalyst and precious metal-based catalyst. Conclusions In summary, we have successfully developed a bifunctional Co/GO catalyst for CO oxidation at low temperature. Through test at the same conditions, it is discovered that a single cobalt and graphene oxide catalysts have the lower CO activity, but their combined Co/GO sample exhibits an unexpected, surprisingly high CO activity that is further enhanced by a series of oxygen-containing functional groups on the surface of graphene oxide sheets, and promoted the activation of O2 molecule. The Co/GO–300°C sample exhibits the outstanding catalytic activity but superior stability, making it a high-performance non-precious metal-based catalyst for CO oxidation elimination. Besides, Co/RG and Co/RGO samples exhibited the lower CO activity than Co/GO sample due to the elimination of oxygen-containing functional groups. Through the modulation of calcination temperature, it is concluded that the unusual catalytic activity of Co/GO–300°C sample arises from the synergistic effect between Co3+ species and the oxygen-containing functional groups of graphene oxide sheets. Therefore, this paper not only paves the way for rational design and synthesis of non-precious Co-based catalyst with controllable morphology and tunable active sites, but also deepens our understanding about the synergetic catalysis. coredata.dc:description: Despite tremendous efforts, developing a series of heterogeneous catalysts for CO oxidation elimination with high activity at low cost remains a great challenge. Here, we report a bifunctional Co-based nanocrystals anchoring in the graphene oxide layer as a high-performance catalyst for CO oxidation. Although a single cobalt or graphene oxide catalysts alone have the lower catalytic activity, their combination exhibits an unexpected, surprisingly high CO activity that is further enhanced by a series of oxygen-containing functional groups on the surface of graphene oxide sheets. The Co/graphene oxide calcined at 300°C (Co/GO–300°C) exhibits the outstanding catalytic activity with T100 =51°C but superior stability, producing a high-performance non-precious metal-based catalyst for CO oxidation elimination. Under a series of critical characterizations, the unusual catalytic activity of Co/GO–300°C sample is attributed to the synergistic effect between the oxygen-containing functional groups of graphene oxide sheets and Co species. Especially, the existence of Co3+ species could promote the adsorption and activation of CO molecules.
coredata.dc:title: Co nanoparticles anchoring three dimensional graphene lattice as bifunctional catalyst for low-temperature CO oxidation
